BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 13, 1911.

The lectures which are given at
the University from time to time
are generally understood to be
principally an element in the course
of, instruction and are, hence, intended especially for the students.
But unfortunately, W far the
greater number of lecturers deal
with topics which are so specialized
that they are either wholly beyond
the average 'undergraduate or,
which is more often the case, are
entirely out of his range of interest.
-It is true that it may be said that
the range of interest of the average
undergraduate is far too narrow.
But we do not think that he is so
much absorbed in other things that
he would not go to hear lecturers,
even on "Chinese Religions," if
those lectures are given in a way
which will put them in reach of the
man with a good general knowledge who is not a specialist in that
particular subject. The complaint
has frequently been made, and we
have even stated it in these columns, that student attendance at
lecttires left much to be desired.
Here is, we think, the real trouble,
and if this can be remedied, McCoy
Hall will be crowded with undercrraduates.
On another page we print an
interesting -communication, dealing
With 'college dramatic societies in
r- ,eneral, and the Haresfoot Club in
particular. There cannot but be
widespread regret that conditions
are such as to compel the suspension of the Club's activities this
year. It is an opportunity for the
pessimist to raise his usual cry that
we have too small an undergraduate body to make a success of these
things. But most of us will con-

cede that this i8 not true. The
Haresfoot Club :,was successful for
two years, and now that the enterMg classes are growing larger.
there is no reason why it should
not be successful in the future. We
hope that the Club will be revived
next year under more auspicious
circumstances and win new successes.
It is amusing to see how we are
all constantly struggling to evolve
some new phrase or to put an old
•word to new Uses so that our language may not become hackneyed,
a term familiar at least to the
freshmen. One of the latest expressions which has been thus
pounced upon and made use of at
every opportunity is the word
"refreshing." Even The Xation in
a single issue used the word no
less than three times in its editorial
columns to describe various incidents which were somewhat out of
the ordinary. When first used the
expression was really "refreshing,"
but it, too, has gone the way of all
flesh.

A comparison of the registration
statistics of the leading colleges,
made by Prof. Rudolf Tombo, Jr.
of Columbia, brings out some very
interesting facts. Of the twentyseven leading institutions, Hopkins
is now twenty-sixth in number of
students, having displaced Virginia, which lost eighty students.
Six institutions have more than
five thousand students—Columbia,
Chicago, I ichigan, Harvard, Pennsylvania and Cornell. Columbia,
with 7,411, has a lead of nearly
1,600 over Chicago with 5,883,
But these figures include the students attending the summer sessions. If we omit the summer session, there is only one college having above 5,000—Columbia, with
5,446. A great many other interesting conclusions are drawn, all
of which may be found in the current number of Science.
The electrical laboratory at Worcester was damaged to the extent
of $200 in a recent riot between
the freshmen and sophomores.

The basketball league is now
making rapid strides. By the good
work of Mr. Kistler, they haw!
now six teams in the league, made
up of graduates and undergraduates. Gillet, the football star, is
on No. 4, and is by far, one of
the best players in the league. Dr.
ag-offin has come back, and is
showing us what an athlete he is.
The teams are very evenly matched,
as is shown by the close scores.
Standing of the teams:

Norman Boyer, 'oi, is managin:2,
editor of The Smart Set. M r.
Boyer was an associate editor of
the Hullabaloo, and an associate
editor and editor-in-chief of THE
NEws-LETTER from 1898 to 1901.
During his ,entire residence at the
University, he was actively interested in journalistic work, being
a correspondent for several Baltimore papers and for the New York
Tribune.

The heaviest football player at
Yale since 1900, weighed 265
pounds ; the tallest man was six
feet four inches ; and the oldest
was twenty-six years.

There recently appeared from the
press of Henry Holt & Co. a volume
of essays dedicated to Frederick
Jackson Turner, Ph. D., '90, professor of. American history at the
University of Wisconsin, by his
former pupils. Professor Turner
was president of the American
Historical Association during the
year 1909-1o.

The Yale News has compiled
some interesting statistics with regard to the reading of the students
at Yale. The number of books borrowed in one year from several
libraries, not including the University library, were as follows:
Modern English and American
fiction, 3,621 ; English and American belles-lettres, 3,317; general
literature, excepting English and
American, 1,820; history and biography, 1,240; fine arts and music,
417; religion and church history.
379; geography and travel, 373;
social science and education, 362;
natural science, 380; philosophy.
199.
Comparing this with the figure
compiled in 1903, several interesting facts are brought out. The
order of the first four classes is
the same. An increasing attention
has, however, been paid to fine arts
and music.
The largest number of books
was drawn out by the faculty,
nineteen per cent, of the total.
Next came the graduate school
with 15 per cent. The least number
was drawn out by the medical men,
68 out of 12,658 books.
• Last Saturday the Intercollegiate
Hockey League closed the season
with the championship in the possession of Cornell. The Ithacans won
five games without a loss. Harvard
followed closely with four games
won and one lost, and Yale and
Columbia tied for third place with
two apiece tO the good and three
games on the other side. Princeton tailed the league with one game
won and four lost.
The average of this year's freshman class at Yale is 19 years.

Michigan students are assessed
a library fee of two dollars, the
money to be devoted to the purchase of new books.
A canvas of representative students at Chicago shows the concensus,of opinion in favor of the
honor system.
There are only thirty student;
from west of the Missippi in this
year's freshman class at Yale.
The new Carnegie swimming
pool at Yale will be used this winter for a series of aquatic contests.
Kansas University has, according to reports, suspended four of
her students for crooked work in
class politics.
At the University of Kansas,
seven fraternaties, representing 170
men, have arranged for a course
of lectures on the Bible, and 200
other men are enrolled in systematic Bible study.
The Hyde lectures will not be
given at Harvard this year, owing
to the inability to obtain a sathfactory lecturer.
Judge Ben Lindsey, of the Juvenile Court in Denver, lectured at
Harvard University last Tuesday.
Gifts amounting to nearly $2,000poo were announced at the
meeting of the trustees of Columbia University last Monday afternoon.
Washington University has its
own printing plant. Its newspaper
has a wireless station and publishes
messages from the \Vest and
United Press.
The seniors won an inter-class
meet at Massachusetts Institute of
Technology, while the juniors,
sophomores and freshmen followed
in their respective order.

The University of Wisconsin has
organized an advertising club with
the idea of securing more ads for
the daily paper.

THE NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 13, 1911
The Haresfoot Club.

The Haresfoot Club is dead.
After .an existence of two years,
the 'first enterprise of Hopkins
undergraduates in the field of
. dramatic art has drawn to a conclusion. The occasion might excuse
our making a few remarks concerning the influence which college
dramatic societies have in their
power to exert at .the present .day.
Never before has the American
stage sunk to its present level of
vapidity and inanity.
ever before were so few good plays exhibited. Never before was public
taste so empty and so vulgar. But
by far the . greatest reason for regret is that this vulgarity of taste
is not confined to those who can
be excused for being- vulgar. Several weeks ago, we printed in our
.columns the results of a vote taken
at the University Of Chicago, to
discover what type of play was the
most popular among its student;.
.The musical comedy carried the
day.
The college dramatic club, therefore, whose management is imbued
with a true love and respect for
the dramatic art will find before ;t
a vast field of endeavor and a heavy
responsibility. It can do but little,
to be sure. It can seldom present
more than a single piece during an
entire season. But for that reason
it should be all the more anxious
that the piece must be most thoroughly excellent which it can find.
It should not merely take up some
play which in • recent years has
"made a hit.- It should examine
carefully the productions of the
rising iday \Tights who take their
profession seriously.
It should
search through the plays of the
past, produced when play-writing
was still a branch of literature. It
will then make its selection only
after careful deliberation.
Of course it is not to be expected that a college dramatic society should undertake Shakespeare.
Nor is it our meaning that it should
attempt the productions of Ben
Jonson, Dryden, Congreye, and a
forgotten troop of lesser worthies.
But we do think ,that the plays of
.Goldsmith and Sheridan would not
be unmeet for it, and we feel sure
that there are a goodly number of
equally appropriate pieces buried
away amid the debris of the past.
But,better still, there is a rising generation of playwrights who bid fair
to restore their profession to its Ormer elevation. And it is the play§ of
these writers that a college dramatic
society should be ever upon the
lookout to welcome and examine.
Nor should it be considered necessary that only humorous realistic
comedies be selected ; there is plenty
of room in the world today for
something that is ideal and fanciful. Were the Haresfoot Club to
continue its career, for instance, we
can think of nothing more worthy
of its examination and consideration than a • play which, though we,
ourselves, have not read it, conies
to us With high recommendation—
"Miss Peabody's Pipers."

Nevertheless, on the whole, we
have no great .fault to find with the
Haresfoot Club. For its opportunities, it has done well. It has given
tis Pinero's "Magistrate,- and, last
year, a play which, though not intrinsically so worthy as its predecessor, was at least not a musical
comedy. Perhaps if the Club's
brief existence had been prolonged
it might have accomplished greater
things. We therefore wish to exTress our regret for its untimely
end.

Mary Johnston

At Yale, they have an annual
fresh mandebate instead
of a debate between the upper
classmen as here. Cups are awarded to the members of the winning
team. "The Fortification of the
Canal- is the subject of this year's
debate.
Yale has narrowed its elective
system to courses, with a view of
preventing the student from dissipating his energies on unrelated
work. It is believed that under
this plan a man will avoid getting
a mere smattering of many subjects, and will acquire a more comprehensive view of those which he
does pursue.
The faculty of the Academic
department at Yale is considering
the removal of entrance examinations in history, English and science. They may accept a certificate
of approved preparatory school in;
these subjects, but_ Nvill examine in
foreign languages and mathematic3.

Last Thursday, in spite of tumults, fights and riots, as the larg-c
clock in the lobby of the Rennert
Hotel struck seven, forty-two freshmen sat down to their first annual
banquet. Three men came in late,
thus swelling the number 'present
to forty-five.
For several days before the banquet, the sophomores had been
making more or less abortive efforts
to break it up. The freshmen, however, showed a remarkable amount
of organization, and by their
staunch loyalty to one another
thwarted what moves the sophomores made.
While the •banquet was being
served, the freshmen sang an.:1
cheered, and the feeling of goodfellowship ran high. A cheer was
(-riven for Dr. Hulburt, who e
cused the men from the mathematical conference Thursday afternoon.
As the last course was cleared
away, and cigarettes were lighted,
Toastmaster Hollyday rose and introduced the president of the class,
Mr. E. B. Riley. President Riley
spoke about the achievements of
the class on the football, baseball
and lacrosse fields, and on the
track. Following him, Mr. Hollyday introduced John L. Dorsey,
captain of the football team. Mr.
Dorsey spoke on the defeat of the
sophomores last fall, and a cheer
was given for each member of the
team. Mr. Wells spoke next on
the track-meet with the sophomores, followed by a speech from
Mr. White, on next year's sophomore class.
The next men who spoke were
the speakers of tile evening. Mr.
Barton spoke on "The Queens
that 1914 had at all of the college
entertainments. Mr. George E. Dorsey spoke on THE X1ws-LETTER.
Mr. Sutton referred to the poor
sophs that were outside looking in,
"like fiends looking into paradise."
Mr. Hammond gave an extended
dissertation upon the conglomerated opinions of chess playing, followed by a. short, .breezy talk by
Mr. Frank Leland. Johnny Yost
gave a dialogue on "The Queens,"
also. He was followed by the
pride of the class, Mr. Schreiber,
who read some poetry of his own
composition, about several members of the sophomore class.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 13, 1911.

The lectures which are given at
the University from time to time
are generally understood to be
principally an element in the course
of, instruction and are, hence, intended especially for the students.
But unfortunately, W far the
greater number of lecturers deal
with topics which are so specialized
that they are either wholly beyond
the average 'undergraduate or,
which is more often the case, are
entirely out of his range of interest.
-It is true that it may be said that
the range of interest of the average
undergraduate is far too narrow.
But we do not think that he is so
much absorbed in other things that
he would not go to hear lecturers,
even on "Chinese Religions," if
those lectures are given in a way
which will put them in reach of the
man with a good general knowledge who is not a specialist in that
particular subject. The complaint
has frequently been made, and we
have even stated it in these columns, that student attendance at
lecttires left much to be desired.
Here is, we think, the real trouble,
and if this can be remedied, McCoy
Hall will be crowded with undercrraduates.
On another page we print an
interesting -communication, dealing
With 'college dramatic societies in
r- ,eneral, and the Haresfoot Club in
particular. There cannot but be
widespread regret that conditions
are such as to compel the suspension of the Club's activities this
year. It is an opportunity for the
pessimist to raise his usual cry that
we have too small an undergraduate body to make a success of these
things. But most of us will con-

cede that this i8 not true. The
Haresfoot Club :,was successful for
two years, and now that the enterMg classes are growing larger.
there is no reason why it should
not be successful in the future. We
hope that the Club will be revived
next year under more auspicious
circumstances and win new successes.
It is amusing to see how we are
all constantly struggling to evolve
some new phrase or to put an old
•word to new Uses so that our language may not become hackneyed,
a term familiar at least to the
freshmen. One of the latest expressions which has been thus
pounced upon and made use of at
every opportunity is the word
"refreshing." Even The Xation in
a single issue used the word no
less than three times in its editorial
columns to describe various incidents which were somewhat out of
the ordinary. When first used the
expression was really "refreshing,"
but it, too, has gone the way of all
flesh.

A comparison of the registration
statistics of the leading colleges,
made by Prof. Rudolf Tombo, Jr.
of Columbia, brings out some very
interesting facts. Of the twentyseven leading institutions, Hopkins
is now twenty-sixth in number of
students, having displaced Virginia, which lost eighty students.
Six institutions have more than
five thousand students—Columbia,
Chicago, I ichigan, Harvard, Pennsylvania and Cornell. Columbia,
with 7,411, has a lead of nearly
1,600 over Chicago with 5,883,
But these figures include the students attending the summer sessions. If we omit the summer session, there is only one college having above 5,000—Columbia, with
5,446. A great many other interesting conclusions are drawn, all
of which may be found in the current number of Science.

of $200 in a recent riot between
the freshmen and sophomores.

The Yale News has compiled
some interesting statistics with regard to the reading of the students
at Yale. The number of books borrowed in one year from several
libraries, not including the University library, were as follows:
Modern English and American
fiction, 3,621 ; English and American belles-lettres, 3,317; general
literature, excepting English and
American, 1,820; history and biography, 1,240; fine arts and music,
417; religion and church history.
379; geography and travel, 373;
social science and education, 362;
natural science, 380; philosophy.
199.
Comparing this with the figure
compiled in 1903, several interesting facts are brought out. The
order of the first four classes is
the same. An increasing attention
has, however, been paid to fine arts
and music.
The largest number of books
was drawn out by the faculty,
nineteen per cent, of the total.
Next came the graduate school
with 15 per cent. The least number
was drawn out by the medical men,
68 out of 12,658 books.
• Last Saturday the Intercollegiate
Hockey League closed the season
with the championship in the possession of Cornell. The Ithacans won
five games without a loss. Harvard
followed closely with four games
won and one lost, and Yale and
Columbia tied for third place with
two apiece tO the good and three
games on the other side. Princeton tailed the league with one game
won and four lost.
The average of this year's freshman class at Yale is 19 years.

Michigan students are assessed
a library fee of two dollars, the
money to be devoted to the purchase of new books.
A canvas of representative students at Chicago shows the concensus,of opinion in favor of the
honor system.
There are only thirty student;
from west of the Missippi in this
year's freshman class at Yale.
The new Carnegie swimming
pool at Yale will be used this winter for a series of aquatic contests.
Kansas University has, according to reports, suspended four of
her students for crooked work in
class politics.
At the University of Kansas,
seven fraternaties, representing 170
men, have arranged for a course
of lectures on the Bible, and 200
other men are enrolled in systematic Bible study.
The Hyde lectures will not be
given at Harvard this year, owing
to the inability to obtain a sathfactory lecturer.
Judge Ben Lindsey, of the Juvenile Court in Denver, lectured at
Harvard University last Tuesday.
Gifts amounting to nearly $2,000poo were announced at the
meeting of the trustees of Columbia University last Monday afternoon.
Washington University has its
own printing plant. Its newspaper
has a wireless station and publishes
messages from the \Vest and
United Press.
The seniors won an inter-class
meet at Massachusetts Institute of
Technology, while the juniors,
sophomores and freshmen followed
in their respective order.

The University of Wisconsin has
organized an advertising club with
the idea of securing more ads for
the daily paper.

THE NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 13, 1911
The Haresfoot Club.

The Haresfoot Club is dead.
After .an existence of two years,
the 'first enterprise of Hopkins
undergraduates in the field of
. dramatic art has drawn to a conclusion. The occasion might excuse
our making a few remarks concerning the influence which college
dramatic societies have in their
power to exert at .the present .day.
Never before has the American
stage sunk to its present level of
vapidity and inanity.
ever before were so few good plays exhibited. Never before was public
taste so empty and so vulgar. But
by far the . greatest reason for regret is that this vulgarity of taste
is not confined to those who can
be excused for being- vulgar. Several weeks ago, we printed in our
.columns the results of a vote taken
at the University Of Chicago, to
discover what type of play was the
most popular among its student;.
.The musical comedy carried the
day.
The college dramatic club, therefore, whose management is imbued
with a true love and respect for
the dramatic art will find before ;t
a vast field of endeavor and a heavy
responsibility. It can do but little,
to be sure. It can seldom present
more than a single piece during an
entire season. But for that reason
it should be all the more anxious
that the piece must be most thoroughly excellent which it can find.
It should not merely take up some
play which in • recent years has
"made a hit.- It should examine
carefully the productions of the
rising iday \Tights who take their
profession seriously.
It should
search through the plays of the
past, produced when play-writing
was still a branch of literature. It
will then make its selection only
after careful deliberation.
Of course it is not to be expected that a college dramatic society should undertake Shakespeare.
Nor is it our meaning that it should
attempt the productions of Ben
Jonson, Dryden, Congreye, and a
forgotten troop of lesser worthies.
But we do think ,that the plays of
.Goldsmith and Sheridan would not
be unmeet for it, and we feel sure
that there are a goodly number of
equally appropriate pieces buried
away amid the debris of the past.
But,better still, there is a rising generation of playwrights who bid fair
to restore their profession to its Ormer elevation. And it is the play§ of
these writers that a college dramatic
society should be ever upon the
lookout to welcome and examine.
Nor should it be considered necessary that only humorous realistic
comedies be selected ; there is plenty
of room in the world today for
something that is ideal and fanciful. Were the Haresfoot Club to
continue its career, for instance, we
can think of nothing more worthy
of its examination and consideration than a • play which, though we,
ourselves, have not read it, conies
to us With high recommendation—
"Miss Peabody's Pipers."

Nevertheless, on the whole, we
have no great .fault to find with the
Haresfoot Club. For its opportunities, it has done well. It has given
tis Pinero's "Magistrate,- and, last
year, a play which, though not intrinsically so worthy as its predecessor, was at least not a musical
comedy. Perhaps if the Club's
brief existence had been prolonged
it might have accomplished greater
things. We therefore wish to exTress our regret for its untimely
end.

Mary Johnston

At Yale, they have an annual
fresh mandebate instead
of a debate between the upper
classmen as here. Cups are awarded to the members of the winning
team. "The Fortification of the
Canal- is the subject of this year's
debate.
Yale has narrowed its elective
system to courses, with a view of
preventing the student from dissipating his energies on unrelated
work. It is believed that under
this plan a man will avoid getting
a mere smattering of many subjects, and will acquire a more comprehensive view of those which he
does pursue.
The faculty of the Academic
department at Yale is considering
the removal of entrance examinations in history, English and science. They may accept a certificate
of approved preparatory school in;
these subjects, but_ Nvill examine in
foreign languages and mathematic3.

Last Thursday, in spite of tumults, fights and riots, as the larg-c
clock in the lobby of the Rennert
Hotel struck seven, forty-two freshmen sat down to their first annual
banquet. Three men came in late,
thus swelling the number 'present
to forty-five.
For several days before the banquet, the sophomores had been
making more or less abortive efforts
to break it up. The freshmen, however, showed a remarkable amount
of organization, and by their
staunch loyalty to one another
thwarted what moves the sophomores made.
While the •banquet was being
served, the freshmen sang an.:1
cheered, and the feeling of goodfellowship ran high. A cheer was
(-riven for Dr. Hulburt, who e
cused the men from the mathematical conference Thursday afternoon.
As the last course was cleared
away, and cigarettes were lighted,
Toastmaster Hollyday rose and introduced the president of the class,
Mr. E. B. Riley. President Riley
spoke about the achievements of
the class on the football, baseball
and lacrosse fields, and on the
track. Following him, Mr. Hollyday introduced John L. Dorsey,
captain of the football team. Mr.
Dorsey spoke on the defeat of the
sophomores last fall, and a cheer
was given for each member of the
team. Mr. Wells spoke next on
the track-meet with the sophomores, followed by a speech from
Mr. White, on next year's sophomore class.
The next men who spoke were
the speakers of tile evening. Mr.
Barton spoke on "The Queens
that 1914 had at all of the college
entertainments. Mr. George E. Dorsey spoke on THE X1ws-LETTER.
Mr. Sutton referred to the poor
sophs that were outside looking in,
"like fiends looking into paradise."
Mr. Hammond gave an extended
dissertation upon the conglomerated opinions of chess playing, followed by a. short, .breezy talk by
Mr. Frank Leland. Johnny Yost
gave a dialogue on "The Queens,"
also. He was followed by the
pride of the class, Mr. Schreiber,
who read some poetry of his own
composition, about several members of the sophomore class.
